name: NPR
text:
New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s new executive order allows businesses to refuse entrance to anyone not wearing a face mask.

"People don't have a right to jeopardize other people's health," Cuomo tweeted.
https://t.co/PTjxXgZTLM

name: NPR
text: A purely economic analysis of coronavirus risks that frontline workers face suggests that hazard pay should be closer to $10 or $20 more an hour, according to calculations by a Columbia University economist. https://t.co/ysR7IMbrf9

name: NPR
text:
School leaders are warning of a financial meltdown that could devastate many districts — and set back an entire generation of students.

"We're about to see a school funding crisis unlike anything we have ever seen in modern history," one expert says.
 
https://t.co/4gI52s9wpP

name: NPR
text: NASA astronauts are heading to space from U.S. soil for the first time in nine years aboard SpaceX's Dragon capsule. https://t.co/3mAR2cmSQJ

name: NPR
text:
ICYMI: Sen. Mitch McConnell says the next coronavirus response bill will be the "final" — and that he won't support extending the $600 in federal unemployment benefits that run out at the end of July.
https://t.co/oDXyLvGP94

name: NPR
text:
Many people with dementia who fall ill can’t express their symptoms, and early coronavirus markers may look similar to their other pre-existing conditions.

That means COVID-19 can go undiagnosed in the early stages. @hereandnow https://t.co/cRuonGCVlP

name: NPR
text:
Michael Ortiz had already spent a year and a half working toward his goal of 100 100-mile races in 100 weeks. He’d be sad to see it end because he was supposed to stay inside.

"But there is a solution. ... Running 13,200 loops of your living room."
 https://t.co/zrXIVMPBDO

name: NPR
text:
Jordan has the site where Jesus was baptized — but Israel manages to attract more tourists to a rival site on the western side of the Jordan River. 

Jordan is looking to change that. https://t.co/Ei92Dx4HSb

name: NPR
text: At a time when voters are increasingly turning toward mail-in voting, the U.S. Postal Service is facing significant challenges — including ridicule from the president, financial woes and new management. https://t.co/mvi9OR0iXc

name: NPR
text:
This 85-year-old and her husband have updated their will. Now, they're working on a living will. 

"I had never thought that I would want to write down 'Do not ventilate,'" she said. "There are other people who need them more, and I have had a good life." 
https://t.co/beEMuMUHew

name: NPR
text: "If we do have the courage to move to a more realistic, hopeful view of human nature, then we can move to a very different kind of society as well," author Rutger Bregman says. "It's actually quite revolutionary." https://t.co/WtDkJbt3dg

name: NPR
text:
Protests for George Floyd continue in dozens of cities across the U.S., as curfews were set and National Guard soldiers deployed.

California Gov. Gavin Newsom declared declared a state of emergency for Los Angeles County. https://t.co/zguOO8KORS

name: NPR
text:
A large portion of U.S. coronavirus cases are centered on New York City. 

Since March 20, New York state, Connecticut and New Jersey have accounted for about 50% of all U.S. cases. As of April 9, nearly 60% of all deaths have been in these three states. https://t.co/h8bPnTGUyc

name: NPR
text:
Both President Trump and China's President Xi Jinping have faced criticism for their handling of the coronavirus outbreak. 

Success with a vaccine at home could make up for the earlier shortcomings. https://t.co/lL4Tc6HkI9

name: NPR
text:
The groundwork for sending NASA astronauts on a commercial space vehicle goes back more than a decade. 

It proceeded steadily under both Republican and Democratic administrations. https://t.co/NZSQ58zUQa

name: NPR
text: "It is very painful to see another black man killed at the hands of the police for basically doing nothing worthy of dying for," said Clarence Castile, the uncle of Philando Castile. https://t.co/uwBDniOB1i

name: NPR
text: Overnight curfews were enacted in several cities nationwide — including Chicago, Atlanta, Los Angeles, Louisville, San Francisco and Denver — and the National Guard was activated in several states. https://t.co/QCJu38B7bh

name: NPR
text: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and Josep Borrell, the EU's top diplomat, called on President Trump to reconsider his plans, saying "actions that weaken international results" during the coronavirus pandemic "must be avoided." https://t.co/ADmAErqMVQ

name: NPR
text:
China has announced a bill that would allow them to directly respond to Hong Kong protesters, circumventing the territory's eroding semi-autonomy.

From @throughlineNPR: what Hong Kongers have been fighting for⤵️
https://t.co/vwXprUITBj

name: NPR
text: Say hello to "jökla-mýs" or "glacier mice." https://t.co/Nh5pY50p9u

name: NPR
text:
Some do's and don'ts of showing up for the people in your life:
- Ask how you can best help
- Lean away from clichés
- Showing up isn't a one-time thing

More from @NPRLifeKit: https://t.co/7OGglE2aNi

name: NPR
text:
"Let's light this candle," astronaut Doug Hurley said before ignition, borrowing words uttered by America's first astronaut.

Yesterday's SpaceX launch marked the first time in nine years that NASA astronauts are heading to space from U.S. soil. https://t.co/5Q6mWwlShQ

name: NPR
text:
Los Angeles is just one city among many across the nation struggling to stem unrest and anger, following decades of racially motivated police brutality. 

More from @LAist: https://t.co/i6i5LrmWmb

name: NPR
text: Two NASA astronauts have arrived at the International Space Station, 19 hours after launching from Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Saturday.  https://t.co/ny4QeTJXwR

name: NPR
text:
@WBEZ Protestors in Chicago chanted “no justice, no peace” as they made their way downtown by foot, bike and car during the second straight day of demonstrations for George Floyd. 

Here are some photos from @WBEZ: https://t.co/bNea5ARtah

name: NPR
text: RT @_aswesterman: This is the intersection where George Floyd was killed last week. Emotions are high there. There is anger and desperation, but also HOPE. @NoelKing & I are on the ground in #Minnesota. Hear us on @NPR @MorningEdition tomorrow: https://t.co/ws7EkBB6TxThis is the intersection where George Floyd was killed last week. Emotions are high there. There is anger and despe… https://t.co/6puJNgUvVM

name: NPR
text: Watch pianist Laura Downes, at home in Sacramento, reimagine old spirituals and songs of freedom that continue to resonate in new ways. https://t.co/xGWFfLiUXT

name: NPR
text:
Black Americans killed by police, like George Floyd. 

Black Americans killed by white men in the South, as Ahmaud Arbery was. 

Black Americans dying disproportionately of COVID-19. 

Saturday, in Seattle and nationwide, the response was collective anger. https://t.co/aQmhvZNkcU

name: NPR
text:
On May 31, 1921, white mobs set fire to more than 1,000 homes and businesses in the Greenwood district of Tulsa — an African American neighborhood known for its thriving middle-class. 

Hundreds were killed and thousands left homeless. (From our archive) https://t.co/ZyhBEHLRtX

name: NPR
text:
Demonstrators and police clashed this weekend as anguish and rage swept through cities across the country in response to the death of George Floyd.

Here are images from some of the protests. https://t.co/1IMkCQ7DeX https://t.co/V5ggHMe0ed

name: NPR
text:
RT @NPRCodeSwitch: We’ve got a new Word Watch for your Sunday reading. 

@JessicaLipsky wrote about how “boogaloo” is being used by extremists to call for civil war. But the word’s original roots are in a dance/music genre made by and for black and brown folks. https://t.co/1uVmIannZe

name: NPR
text:
President Trump once called him "the world's most conservative human being," but many top Iowa Republicans have abandoned Rep. Steve King over his history of offensive and racist comments.  

Now, he's fighting to hang onto his seat. https://t.co/ctGAA2Q6pr

name: NPR
text:
As overlapping crises convulsed an anxious nation, President Trump sought to cast blame for widespread protests on "radical-left anarchists." 

He also said the media "is doing everything within their power to foment hatred and anarchy." 
https://t.co/J6cv5rZ0OP

name: NPR
text: RT @lourdesgnavarro: So important to have @HannahAllam separate fact from fiction on allegations of far-right or far-left agitators in the protests. Listen. https://t.co/N8B2FEMOdc

name: NPR
text:
President Trump once called him "the world's most conservative human being." But many top Iowa Republicans have abandoned Rep. Steve King, who has a history of offensive and racist comments.  

Now, he's fighting to hang onto his seat. https://t.co/dXt58bS9PE

name: NPR
text:
Think of a familiar three-word name of something. 

The first word in that name is a number. 

Let's call that number "x." 

The last "x" letters of the second word of the name are a French translation of the third word. 

What's the name? https://t.co/2npnLFFZji

name: NPR
text:
Minneapolis paid out $3 million dollars to settle a lawsuit over the 2010 death of David Smith. 

The young black man died after an officer pinned him down with a knee on his back for several minutes.
https://t.co/1qRdqUrEU1
